Content: *p70655a0224*2	  answer all questions.1	 the photograph shows part of a field of kenaf plants, hibiscus cannabinus.(source: © design pics inc / alamy stock photo)	crops of kenaf plants are grown throughout asia. 	several products are extracted from these plants: •	oil can be extracted from the seeds and this oil can be used as a biofuel•	fibres can be extracted from the stems and used to make sustainable materials.
*p70655a0324*turn over     3	  	(a)	 describe an experiment to measure the tensile strength of fibres that have been extracted from these plants.(6)

*p70655a0424*4	  	(b)	 cellulose is a major component of plant fibres.		describe the structure of a cellulose molecule. (3)	(c)	 give one reason why the use of biofuels can reduce the effects of climate change. (1)(total for question 1 = 10 marks)

*p70655a0524*turn over     5	  2	 the photograph shows a garden snail, helix aspersa. this species is endemic to western europe.(source: © max mumby / alamy stock photo)	snails feed on plants in warm, moist conditions.	in dry conditions, snails seal the entrance to their shell with a membrane.	the photograph shows this membrane.membrane(source: © premaphotos / alamy stock photo)

*p70655a0624*6	  	a student investigated the volume of water needed to stimulate snails to break through the membranes at the entrance to their shells.	the student used the following method.	a group of 15 snails with membranes was used in this investigation.	the diagram shows how each snail was held upside down.membranesupportsnail	each snail had two drops of water added to the membrane every minute. 	the time taken for each snail to break through the membrane was recorded. 	(a)	 suggest one reason why the student thought it was ethical to use snails in this investigation.(1)

*p70655a0724*turn over     7	  	(b)	 the table shows the results of this investigation.number of drops of water added4080120160200total number of snails breaking through the membrane147910		the mean diameter of each spherical drop of water was 3.0 mm.		calculate the volume of water added to a snail in one minute. 		the volume of a sphere can be calculated using the formula:v = 43 πr3			give your answer in mm3, to two significant figures.(3)answer  mm3

*p70655a0824*8	  	(c)	 (i)	 give two abiotic variables, other than the independent variable, that could affect this experiment.(2)1 2 		(ii)	 name one of the variables you have identified in (i). 			variable 			state how this variable could be controlled. (1)		(iii)	suggest the effect that not controlling this variable could have on the results.(1)

*p70655a0924*turn over     9	  	(d)	 the student decided to repeat the investigation using the same apparatus but adding four drops of water every minute. 		there was no significant difference in the results when the number of drops added each minute doubled. 		suggest why this did not have an effect on the time it took the snails to break through the membrane.(2)(total for question 2 = 10 marks)

*p70655a01024*10	  3	 the photograph shows a species of mayfly nymph. mayfly nymphs live in streams and rivers on every continent except antarctica.(source: © naturepics / alamy stock photo)	many species of mayfly nymph are found in unpolluted streams. 	all mayfly species have a three-pronged tail.	there are fewer species and lower numbers of each species in polluted streams.	a student read a report that low levels of chlorpyrifos (an insecticide) may have entered some streams.	the student used the method shown in the diagram to collect mayfly nymphs.	samples were collected from unpolluted stream a and polluted stream b.
